Timing Class Reference

#include <Timing.h>

List of all members.

Detailed Description

The timing determines the way to synchronize the application (or game) to the clock and provides functionality for time dependant calculations.

Author:
Thomas Jacob

Definition at line 23 of file Timing.h.

Member Function Documentation

unsigned long getLastTime (   ) 
 

Returns the last frame's time since the program start in milli seconds.

Returns:
The time in milli seconds.

unsigned long getMaximumFrameTime (   ) 
 

Returns the maximum time a frame shall take in milli seconds.

If a frame takes longer than this time, the Timing class issues that only maximumFrameTime milli seconds elapsed. This is just to make sure that if any real time calculation takes longer than real time, the whole thing cannot build up. Defaults to the DEFAULT_MAXIMUM_FRAME_TIME.

Returns:
The maximum frame time in milli seconds.
See also:
DEFAULT_MAXIMUM_FRAME_TIME

unsigned long getMinimumFrameTime (   ) 
 

Returns the minimum time a frame shall take.

After all other frame routines (such as InputManager::handle and Renderer::frame) have been executed, the Timing waits so that the whole time (including the routines) of the frame is at least this amount. Use a positive value larger than the maximum time of your routines to choose the deterministic model: All frames will take that long then. Use 0 for e.g. 3D games, as they strive for maximum frame rates.

Returns:
The minimum time a frame shall take.

unsigned long getTime (   ) 
 

Returns this frame's time since the program start in milli seconds.

Returns:
The time in milli seconds.

void setMaximumFrameTime (  unsigned long  maximumFrameTime  ) 
 

Sets the maximum time a frame shall take in milli seconds.

If a frame takes longer than this time, the Timing class issues that only maximumFrameTime milli seconds elapsed. This is just to make sure that if any real time calculation takes longer than real time, the whole thing cannot build up. Defaults to the DEFAULT_MAXIMUM_FRAME_TIME.

Parameters:
maximumFrameTime The maximum frame time in milli seconds.
See also:
DEFAULT_MAXIMUM_FRAME_TIME

void setMinimumFrameTime (  unsigned long  minimumFrameTime  ) 
 

Sets the minimum time a frame shall take.

After all other frame routines (such as InputManager::handle and Renderer::frame) have been executed, the Timing waits so that the whole time (including the routines) of the frame is at least this amount. Use a positive value larger than the maximum time of your routines to choose the deterministic model: All frames will take that long then. Use 0 for e.g. 3D games, as they strive for maximum frame rates.

Parameters:
minimumFrameTime The minimum time a frame shall take.

void setTime (  bool  noWarnings  )  [private]
 

Sets the next time step of the clock.

See getTimeStep().

Parameters:
noWarnings Normally, if there is much time between two calls to setTime(), a warning message is produced. If you know, that there may be a delay, or if you are in the initialization, set this parameter to true, otherwise, set it to false.
See also:
getTimeStep()

void updateAndWait (   ) 
 

Updates internal variables each frame and checks whether to wait for the minimum frame time to complete.

Member Data Documentation

const int DEFAULT_MAXIMUM_FRAME_TIME [static]
 

The default maximum time for a frame.

This is just to make sure that, if any real time calculation takes longer than real time, the whole thing cannot build up.

unsigned long maximumFrameTime [private]
 

The maximum time a frame shall take in milli seconds.

If a frame takes longer than this time, the Timing class issues that only maximumFrameTime milli seconds elapsed. This is just to make sure that if any real time calculation takes longer than real time, the whole thing cannot build up. Defaults to the DEFAULT_MAXIMUM_FRAME_TIME.

See also:
DEFAULT_MAXIMUM_FRAME_TIME

Definition at line 47 of file Timing.h.

unsigned long minimumFrameTime [private]
 

The minimum time a frame shall take.

After all other frame routines (such as the desktop update and rendering routines, as well as the methods of Scene) have been executed, the Timing waits so that the whole time (including the routines) of the frame is at least this amount. Use a positive value larger than the maximum time of your routines to choose the deterministic model: All frames will take that long then. Use 0 for e.g. 3D games, as they strive for maximum frame rates.
